title: Antun Maqdisi
text:
Antun Maqdisi, also written as Antoun/Anton Maqdesi/Muqaddasi/Moqaddasi (1914 – January 5, 2005; <a href="Syria">Yabrud</a>) was a <a href="Syria">Syria</a>n philosopher, politician and <a href="human%20rights">human rights</a> activist.
He began his study in <a href="Damascus">Damascus</a> and obtained his degree in <a href="Philosophy">Philosophy</a> and <a href="French%20literature">French literature</a> at the <a href="University%20of%20Montpellier">University of Montpellier</a> in <a href="France">France</a>. When he returned in Syria in 1940, he began his career as a teacher in philosophy, initially in <a href="Homs">Homs</a> and later in <a href="Hama">Hama</a>, <a href="Damascus">Damascus</a> and <a href="Aleppo">Aleppo</a>. In <a href="Beirut">Beirut</a> he obtained an academic degree in <a href="Law">Law</a>.
He was one of the co-founders of the <a href="Arab%20Socialist%20Movement">Arab Socialist Movement</a>, that merged in 1953 into the <a href="Ba%27ath%20Party">Ba'ath Party</a> in Syria. He has a <a href="christianity">christian</a> background.
Shortly afterwards he left active politics and continued with scientific work. From 1965 to 2000 he worked on research for the Ministry of Culture and translated and edited a great number of books. In 1969 he founded the <a href="Arab%20Writers%20Union">Arab Writers Union</a>. He helped to establish the Faculty of Philosophy at the <a href="Damascus%20University">Damascus University</a> as well.
In 2001 he was honored with a <a href="Prince%20Claus%20Awards">Prince Claus Award</a> from the <a href="Netherlands">Netherlands</a> for his dedication for <a href="democracy">democracy</a>, <a href="Political%20freedom">freedom</a> and <a href="human%20rights">human rights</a>.
Maqdisi died on January 5, 2005.
